description: Used in English since 15th century, from Middle French permanent, from Latin permanens, from permanēo (“I stay through”).

adjectives.description: permanent (comparative more permanent, superlative most permanent)

examples: Nothing in this world is truly permanent.

entries.meaning: Lasting for an indefinitely long time.
examples: The countries are now locked in a permanent state of conflict.

entries.meaning: A chemical hair treatment imparting or removing curliness, whose effects typically last for a period of weeks; a perm.
examples: She had pewter-coloured hair set in a ruthless permanent, a hard beak and large moist eyes with the sympathetic expression of wet stones.

(collectible card games) A card whose effects persist beyond the turn on which it is played.

verbs.description: permanent (third-person singular simple present permanents, present participle permanenting, simple past and past participle permanented)
